III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section (2) Initial consideration shall be given to placement with a relative
Description and/or placing siblings together.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Failure to do adequate case planning that take into account the
mother's limited cognitive abilities.
Investigation Reporting Source:
The Reporting Source was interviewed on 4/14/2023. It was
reported that Parent 1 has not seen her son (Youth A) in person
since he was moved across the state. The siblings have not seen
each other in person since the move across the state. Foster
Parent 1 requested help from DHHS but did not get it and then
Foster Parent 1 requested the medically fragile child (Youth A) be
moved. No FTM was held before the move. Parent 1 has been
2

given no information about the move except that it occurred, and
the Youth A is still across the state. No relatives were given
serious consideration as placement.
Administrator:
The administrator and Foster Care Supervisor were interviewed
and provided the following case history on 4/28/2023 regarding
case planning of Youth A and Parent 1. Youth A was removed on
12/11/2019 due to severe physical abuse. Parental Rights were
terminated on 2/26/2021 and Youth A and his siblings were made
MCI wards.
On 4/8/2022, Supreme Court overturned Parent 1’s termination of
parental rights and the children became TCW’s again. After being
serviced by several private agencies, on 04/08/2022, Youth A’s
case came back to be serviced by MDHHS direct Foster Care.
Children’s Center maintains full family responsibility. Because of
this, Children’s Center has the majority of the communication with
Youth A’s guardian, Parent 1.
It should be noted that Youth A (3 years old) is medically fragile
due to severe physical abuse that occurred while in the care of his
parents. He is diagnosed with Shaken baby syndrome, sequela at
3 months of age, Non-accidental TBI, Anoxic brain injury, Spastic
dystonic tetraplegic cerebral palsy, Cortical Visual Impairment,
legally blind, Gerd, Dystonia, Oropharyngeal dysphagia (at risk for
aspiration) and Focal Epilepsy. He is non-verbal. He is unable to
sit, stand, or walk. He is prescribed numerous medications due to
his conditions and requires 24/7 care.
The Administrator and Foster Care Supervisor reported that Youth
A is overdue for all of his immunizations. Parent 1 signed an
immunization waiver on 01/21/2021 citing “I don’t want my
children having shots.” Youth A’s injury has resulted in his
muscles becoming extremely tight and spasming. Parent 1 has
been contacted by Mary Free Bed Rehabilitation to obtain consent
to inject Youth A with Botox and phenol into his legs to assist with
his tone, help him be more comfortable, and to help prevent his
need for hip surgery. It was reported that Parent 1 was unwilling to
provide consent for this procedure and refused to speak with the
Pediatric Rehabilitation Physician directly.
The Administrator and Foster Care Supervisor reported Youth A’s
Placement history as follows:
3

From 12/11/2019- 2/10/2022: Relative Placement with paternal
relative in Detroit.
On 2/10/2022- 4/10/2023: Youth A was placed with a licensed
foster parent in Reed City, MI. At the time of placement, Youth A
was an MCI Ward. Foster Parent 1 worked very hard to swiftly get
Youth A in with all the services and specialists he needed. Foster
Parent 1 became increasingly concerned about Youth A not being
able to receive the medical care that will protect him as well as
assist with his comfort because of Parent 1’s unwillingness to
provide the needed medical consents. Foster Parent 1 was also
not prepared to assist with facilitating parental visitations as Youth
A was placed in her home as an MCI Ward. Foster Parent 1 felt
that she was constantly having to prove that the care she was
providing to Youth A was for the right reasons. Foster Parent 1
became frustrated and submitted a 14-day notice requesting
Youth A’s replacement on 03/22/2023.
On 4/10/2023 – Present, Youth A is placed with licensed Foster
Parents 2 in Hudsonville, MI.
Foster Care Supervisor:
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed on 4/28/2023 and
reported the following information regarding Parent 1’s cognitive
abilities. The Foster Care Supervisor reported that MDHHS does
not have any records specifically identifying that Parent 1 has any
cognitive impairments. She said Parent 1 participated with a
psychological evaluation on 08/22/2022. The psychological
evaluation estimated that Parent 1 overall level of intellectual
functioning may fall within or near the “Borderline” range with a
Full-Scale IQ in the 70-79 range. The report stated, “Parent 1
results were not low enough to suggest a diagnosis of a full
intellectual disability or any serious cognitive deficits.”
Foster Care Supervisor said Parent 1 participated with a
psychiatric evaluation on 11/8/2022. The psychiatric evaluation
notes that there were no reports of
developmental/education/social delays. During the evaluation
Parent 1 denied special education services due to learning
disabilities and she reported to meeting all developmental
milestones on time.
Supervisor from Children’s Center:
The Supervisor from Children’s Center was interviewed on
6/6/2023. She reported Family Team Meetings (FTM) are held
4

quarterly as required. The last meeting was a Team Decision
Meeting (TDM) to discuss placement move for Youth A. She
reported the agency is working on scheduling an FTM on
6/12/2023 to discuss the case service plan, treatment plan, and
Parent 1’s children’s needs.
The supervisor reported the foster care workers that have been
assigned to this case are patient with Parent 1 in all
communications. She said the workers take the time to listen to
Parent 1 questions and repeat if needed. She said what works
best with Parent 1 is to give her choices and use shorter
sentences at times to make sure she understands and have
Parent 1 repeat the information back. She said Parent 1 tends to
get angry easily and argumentative if things do not go her way
which have led her to being muted on meetings or requested to
leave the agency premises. Furthermore, the agency has given
Parent 1 resources and the website from Children’s Hospital
regarding trach care for Youth A. The Supervisor said Parent 1
agreed to take a CPR /First Aid class. Parent 1 mentioned she
already took this class and must see if her certification needed to
be renewed. The Supervisor provided the following information
regarding working with Parent 1. She said Parent 1 has been
referred to all court ordered services and accommodations have
been given to Parent 1 to make sure she can attend these
services. Parent 1 has been provided the following
services/accommodations.
Drug screens have been performed at The Children’s Center or
through Assured Family Services. Parenting times have been
supervised at The Children’s Center. Parent 1 was offered twice a
week parenting time but requested her visits be once a week at 2
hours a day with her girls. Parenting classes were through
Assured Family Services and were able to meet with her individual
by virtual appointments. Parent 1 was able to receive a certificate.
Psychological evaluation was virtual and one on one through
Assured Family Services. Psychiatric evaluation was virtual and
one on one through Assured Family Services. Individual therapy
appointments are held weekly virtually. The therapist is aware of
Parent 1’s diagnosis. Infant mental health services are in place for
Parent 1 two daughters and Parent 1 could participate in these
appointments or speak with the therapist separately on their
treatment or questions she may have. Parent 1 has the therapist
phone and email information. Parent 1 was offered supportive
visitation program through Orchards Children’s Services and
Parent 1 denied being a part of this program. The supportive
5

visitation coach did make all attempts to educate Parent 1 on the
program and how they could assist her with her children during
visits and give additional parental education before or after a visit.
Parent 1 was referred for a parent partner support through Judson
Center. Parent 1 initially said yes and then later refused to be a
part of the program. Parent 1 is a part of the Maternal Infant
Health program through Great Start which allows Parent 1 to visit
with a social worker monthly to provide her with social support,
transportation to appointments, and baby items. Parent 1 has a
social worker at New Foster program who visits her monthly in the
home as additional support advocate for Parent 1. The agency
has assisted Parent 1 with referrals to emergency shelters when
she did not have power to her home. The agency offered Uber
and Greyhound bus transportation. Parent 1 does receive therapy,
case management, medication management through Team
Wellness in addition to the services mentioned above.
Documents reviewed:
Youth A’s case file was reviewed on 4/28/2023. He is 3 years old.
He was placed in the same relative placement from 12/11/19 –
2/10/22, with MDHHS and two private agencies having case
responsibilities during that time frame. He was placed with a
licensed foster parent from 2/10/22 – 4/10/23 and with another
licensed foster parent from 4/10/23 to present.
Parent 1’s psychological and psychiatric evaluations. Other than
what was reported regarding parent 1’s results, there was no
additional information.
Analysis Based on interviews, documentation of Parent 1’s psychological
and psychiatric evaluations and the support provided by MDHHS
to Parent 1, it is not substantiated that the agency did not provide
adequate case planning that took into account the Parent 1's
limited cognitive abilities. The agency also provided initial
consideration with relative placement and placing siblings
together.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
Section (1) An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
Description parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(c) Provisions for visits between parents and children except
where parental rights have been terminated or when there is a
court determination that visits are detrimental to the child.
6

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Lack of parental visits.
Investigation Foster Care Supervisor from MDHHS:
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed on 4/28/2023. She
reported when Parent 1’s parental rights were reinstated to Youth
A in April 2022, Youth A was placed approximately three hours
away from Parent 1. Parent 1 reported that she did not have
transportation to get where Youth A was placed to visit with him.
Greyhound bus tickets and gas cards were offered. Parent 1
refused these stating she does not like the bus. Foster Care
Supervisor said transportation and distance are a barrier for in
person visits so on 07/26/2022, the court ordered DHHS the
discretion to utilize virtual visits. She said Youth A is extremely
medically fragile and easily susceptible to infection and not being
current on his immunizations exacerbates this matter. She said
Youth A’s current caregivers are trained on how to adequately
utilize and maintain his g-tube, identify, and intervene regarding
his epilepsy, administer his medication, and provide emergency
care if needed. The caregivers are not willing to assist with
facilitating parenting time visits. The FCS said she nor Parent 1
are currently trained regarding Youth A’s medical needs. She said
this has prohibited the Foster Care staff from picking Youth A up
and taking him to a neutral location for Parent 1 to visit with him.
She said because of not being trained, visits have consistently
occurred virtually. Foster Parent 2 do not have supportive
individuals that is trained on how to care for Youth A that would
also be willing to facilitate visits. She said MDHHS is currently in
contact with Youth A’s medical providers to identify where Parent
1 can be trained regarding how to care for Youth A with his
specific medical needs. The FCS said MDHHS is currently
exploring if there are options with Youth A’s medical providers to
have visits at a local hospital or medical facility.
Supervisor from The Children’s Center:
The Supervisor from Children’s Center was interviewed on
6/6/2023. She reported The Children’s Center has full family
responsibility and DHHS has case responsibility for Youth A. She
reported she know DHHS has been making sure Parent 1 has
been involved in virtual parenting times with Youth A at minimum
once a week. She said Parent 1 does not always show up or
participate in her parenting times with Youth A based on
information from DHHS. She said their agency has not
supervised any parenting times between Youth A and Parent 1.
She said there was one scheduled in person parenting time this
7

year, but Parent 1 cancelled in advance stating she had to attend
to her cash assistance appointment instead. The supervisor said
since then, DHHS has been looking for ways to have in person
visits with Parent 1 and Youth A. She reported that Youth A
needed 24/7 care and a specialized medical professional will need
be present for all supervised parenting times moving forward. She
said it is her understanding that Parent 1 was able to attend a
medical appointment for Youth A in person and DHHS provided
Uber transportation. The supervisor said her agency has offered
to help with transportation and overnight stay if needed for Parent
1.
The supervisor reported that the service plans do discuss Parent 1
diagnosis and includes her treatment plan for her and her children.
She said services and strategies are in place to take into
consideration for the goals and action steps for Parent 1 and her
children. She said however, further development is needed to
include more detailed in the steps to further assist Parent 1.
Analysis Based on interviews from MDHHS and The Children’s Center,
Parent 1 is offered transportation to visit with Youth A. The foster
care staff nor Parent 1 is trained to assist Youth A with his
extensive medical needs. Foster Parent 1 has not accepted the
offer of catching a bus or receiving bus tickets from the agency to
go and visit with Youth A on a more consistent basis. She was
offered transportation by way of Uber which she accepted. There
is not enough evidence to support that the agencies are not
providing transportation to Parent 1 to visit with Youth A on a more
consistent basis.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421Vistation and parenting time
Section (1) An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
Description parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(d) Provisions for visits between siblings who are not placed
together except when there is a court determination that visits are
detrimental to either child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Failure to look at relative placement.
Investigation Foster Care Supervisor:
8

Foster Care Supervisor reported Youth A’s Placement history as
follows:
From 12/11/2019- 2/10/2022: Relative Placement with paternal
relative in Detroit. Paternal relative had placement of Youth A and
his two siblings. She initially signed an intent to adopt all three
children, and then asked the court if she could do guardianship
instead. This request was denied. Parent 1requested Youth A and
one of his siblings be removed from the relative placement home
and that the relative rights be rescinded for her intent to adopt.
All three children ended up being replaced from the relative
home. After Youth A was replaced from the relative home, Youth
A was seen by an abundance of medical specialists. Youth A’s
medical needs were not being properly addressed while in the
relative’s care. It was also identified after Youth A was replaced
that the relative was attempting to receive SSI and foster care
payments for Youth A.
It was reported by the Foster Care Supervisor that no other
relatives have come forth to care for Youth A other than the
relative home where Youth A siblings are placed with. She
reported due to the siblings’ behavioral needs Youth A’s Guardian
Ad Litern (GAL) was not in support of placing Youth A in this
relative home because the GAL feels this would be too much for
the relative to handle based on the extensive medical needs of
Youth A.
Analysis Based on the interview with the Foster Care Supervisor, Youth A
was originally place with a relative who intent was to adopt Youth
A but rescinded her intent. Another relative came forth but this
decision was not accepted by the GAL due to Youth A’s extensive
medical needs. No other relative has come forth. Based on
documentation and interviews, the agency is not in violation of
failure to look at relative placement.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that Wayne County DHHS - Western
current license status be continued.
